week1.title: Who am I?
week1.introParagraph: This week was about getting acquainted with new learning materials and reflecting on personal expectations and discoveries.
headings: Was your first week what you expected? Why? Why not?
What are you excited or eager to learn more about?
What is something about you that can only be learned by reading this blog?
Cool Code Snippet
paragraphs: Honestly, I had no idea what to expect. I've been pleased by the structure and flow of the work so far. I have learned a lot of things I did not know before. I expected to learn a lot; I just wasn't sure exactly how it was going to happen!
I'm very eager to learn Python and Django. I know it's a very marketable skillset to have and it opens up a lot of fun opportunities!

Here's a quick list of some interesting things about me: I have a 1-year-old daughter named Blake. I've been married to my wife Blair for 2 years. I have the unofficial record for the fastest person to eat a 3 way at Skyline Chili (44 seconds) ðŸ’ª. I was a cheerleader in high school and coached cheerleading afterwards.

week2.title: A Taste for Style
week2.introParagraph: This week, I reflected on my current capabilities and challenges within coding, specifically focusing on HTML and CSS, and how I approach problem-solving.
headings: What is something you wish you could do but currently do not have the coding skills to accomplish?
What are you struggling with?
How do you solve a problem?
What methods do you use to help yourself get unstuck?
paragraphs: Thereâ€™s a lot I wish I could do but, when it comes to specifically HTML and CSS, I wish I knew more about what was going on under the hood so that when I run into weird errors or problems, I could better troubleshoot them.
Iâ€™m currently not struggling too bad, but I have run into the problem of getting ahead of myself and trying to learn/comprehend things that are too far beyond my skill set, and it stresses me out.

I solve a problem by thinking it through simply, and writing down the large ideas of what I want to accomplish and then I tackle that step-by-step. I always try to get context before I hyperfocus on the first solution that comes to my head.
I tried to move on to something else and then come back to it. Also getting more context and doing more research, isolate the problem as well and take away as many factors as possible.

week3.title: A New Chapter
week3.introParagraph: What was helpful during onboarding working remotely? What hindered your progress during onboarding? How did you overcome challenges during onboarding?
headings: What I Found Helpful Working Remotely
What Hindered My Progress
Overcoming Challenges
paragraphs: I found separating myself from distractions to be key when working remotely. Especially while working on a project, it's important for me to give it my full attention. I achieved this by working at the library or at night when everyone else is asleep.

The biggest blocker to my progress during onboarding was not properly pseudo-coding. I get too anxious to start coding that I skip spending adequate time planning it out beforehand. This led to logic issues, especially with my alarm clock project, that took me hours of debugging which could have been avoided by proper pseudo-coding.
I overcame challenges by being very active on Slack, reaching out for help, and diving into resources on topics I wasn't familiar with.

week4.title: A New Chapter
week4.introParagraph: Reflecting on my onboarding experience, I contemplate what was helpful while working remotely, what hindered my progress, and how I overcame those challenges.
headings: What I Found Helpful Working Remotely
What Hindered My Progress
Overcoming Challenges
paragraphs: I found separating myself from distractions to be key when working remotely. It's especially important for me to give full attention to my projects. I managed this by working at the library or at night when it was quieter, allowing me to focus completely.

The biggest blocker during onboarding was not properly pseudo-coding. The eagerness to jump into coding meant I didn't spend enough time planning. This led to logic issues in my projects, like the alarm clock, which required extensive debugging that could have been avoided with more thorough pseudo-coding.

I overcame challenges by being very active on Slack, reaching out for help, and diving into resources about topics I was less familiar with. This proactive approach was crucial for navigating through the difficulties I faced.

week5.title: Buoyant
week5.introParagraph: This week has been amazing. Each morning, I'm excited to go to class, absorbing an incredible amount of information faster than I ever have before. Once I'm home, I find myself having to consciously stop from spending the entire evening codingâ€”I'm even dreaming in code! This past week has surpassed my expectations, I feel buoyant and full of optimism.
headings: What held me back this week?
What I wish to learn?
My motivation for web development?
paragraphs: Rushing into the coding phase was my main setback. I realized too late that dedicating more time to planning and pseudo-coding would have prevented the extensive refactoring and overanalysis that consumed two-thirds of my project time.
Iâ€™m looking to deepen my understanding of JSON. It was overlooked in my recent project, yet it's very important for server communication

I'm driven by a desire to create work that stands out, I want to blend creativity with innovation, all while being financially rewarded. Itâ€™s the thrill of seeing my skills directly translate into success that excites me.

week6.title: I'm a Programmer
week6.introParagraph: This week, I truly feel as though I've crossed some very important barriers in my understanding. Now, I think I'm finally confident enough to call myself a programmer.
headings: What things do I feel confident doing?
What did I learn that helped me understand the development process?
What does it mean to develop good code?
What does it mean to be a good developer?
What is one thing that programmers hate doing?
What am I excited to learn moving forward?
paragraphs: I'm beginning to see JavaScript not just as code, but as clear and understandable English. Objects, arrays, functions, methods, parameters, loops, statements, expressionsâ€”all of it now makes perfect sense to me.

Learning how to effectively use functions to create DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) code taught me how to streamline vanilla JavaScript development. Also, using APIs and Node packages showed me that it's okay to integrate other people's code into my projects.
Developing good code means three key things: #1 it has to work, #2 it has to be DRY, #3 it has to be easily readable.

A good developer can code quickly, knows where to look and how to solve problems, and can debug effectively. Most importantly, a good developer delivers quality code that not only works but can also be updated and read by anyone.
Programmers hate typing.
Object-oriented programming has really clicked for me. I'm eager to push my skills further, focusing on creating super DRY code that is efficiently organized.

week7.title: Tired of Vanilla!
headings: Javascript
The Job Search
paragraphs: This week with JavaScript has been a rollercoaster! I'm starting to feel the burnout from using plain vanilla JavaScript, but there's light at the end of the tunnel because we're jumping into React next week, which I absolutely love! The biggest takeaway for me this week is that almost everything in JavaScript is an object... functions, arrays, etc. This realization has shifted how I understand and follow JavaScript code, making unfamiliar features more approachable. I love JavaScript, but manual DOM manipulation isn't my favorite, which is why I'm so excited to start working with React!

Everyone keeps telling me that finding a job won't be a problem, but I can't help feeling skeptical. Is it just my insecurities? Despite these doubts, I'm pushing myself to network more actively, especially on LinkedIn. Just last week, I had lunch with the CEO of a local tech company. They aren't hiring junior developers right now, but things might change by the time I finish my bootcamp. We had a conversation, and he wanted to keep in touch. No promises, but it's given me a huge boost and the motivation to give my all to this bootcamp and my job search. Even though I'm naturally pessimistic, the experiences I'm gaining are slowly but surely helping me shed that negativity.

week7Technical.title: What is Pseudocode?
week7Technical.introParagraph: Pseudocode has been a big focus for me this week. Every day, I've been using it to outline the logic of my projects before I start coding. This approach has drastically improved how I handle complex programming tasks, making me more productive and my code more manageable.
headings: How Pseudocode Has Improved My Coding
The Importance of Pseudocode in My Programming Routine
Enhancing My Pseudocode Skills
paragraphs: At first, I wasn't convinced that spending time writing pseudocode would be worthwhile. But it didn't take long to see its benefits. Pseudocode has saved me from countless hours of backtracking and redoing my work. By clearly defining my thoughts and the flow of operations in simple English first, I've been able to spot and address problems early on.

I now see pseudocode as more than just a preliminary step but it's a crucial part of my coding process. It helps me layout and think through my projects, making the actual coding much smoother. It's also been great for working with others, as it makes my thought process clear and easy to follow.

Moving forward, my goal is to deepen my understanding and use of pseudocode. I want to develop more comprehensive and precise pseudocode for all my projects. By doing so, I believe I can make my coding process not only faster but also significantly more accurate and less prone to errors.

week8.title: How to React?
week8.introParagraph: This week, using React, I created a fake restaurant's site based around a menu API.
headings: Are JavaScript Frameworks User-Friendly?
Exploring React and Possibly Next.js
Planning Finance Tracking Features with Rechart
paragraphs: From my experience, React simplifies the development process once you understand its syntax and flow. It provides built-in functionalities for many common issues faced in vanilla JavaScript, making it an amazing tool for developers familiar with its environment.

Currently, my focus is on React, which I love because of it's robust capabilities for building user interfaces. After the bootcamp, I'm excited to start experimenting with Next.js, hoping it will allow for even more efficient project development.

I'm looking to improve my capstone project with financial tracking capabilities for managers using Rechart. This tool will let me present financial data through interactive and visually appealing charts.

week9.title: CLIs and State Management in React
week9.introParagraph: This week, I explored React's state management techniques, focusing on the `useReducer` and `useContext` hooks.
headings: What have you learned about CLIs? Do you think they are scary?
If you were to build a CLI, what would it do?
List some ideas that without a Framework, would take you a long time to code.
How does `useReducer` change the way you handle state in React applications?
What are the advantages of combining `useContext` with `useReducer` for state management in large applications?
paragraphs: CLIs are just a text interface to interact with your computer. They don't scare me; I think the basic CLI commands are pretty simple to grasp but I haven't explored anything too complex yet. Iâ€™m sure diving deeper will be incredibly beneficial for backend development.
If I created a CLI, it would enable running text commands to navigate through files and launch applications. Just a straightforward, efficient tool for developers.

Trying to code a social media platform without a framework would be very hard. Managing all the data flow, user interactions, and dynamic elements would be overwhelming without the structured support of a framework.

`useReducer` functions similarly to `useState` but gives a more organized approach by centralizing all state logic in one place. I really enjoy using it because it helps managing state less convoluted, especially in complex components.

Using both `useReducer` and `useContext` together is really efficient. You get the structured and centralized state management of `useReducer` along with the convenience of `useContext`, which allows you to avoid the dreaded prop drilling that comes with just `useState`. This combination simplifies passing state through your components.

week10.title: Learning Python
week10.introParagraph: This week we started learning Python. I learned a few things about myself and how I operate this week.
headings: First Week Experience
Excitement for Learning
Coding Habits
Project Highlight
paragraphs: Honestly, I was nervous to learn a new language because I felt like there is still so much to learn about JavaScript (JS) and Iâ€™ve been learning it for a while now. However, the transition went surprisingly smooth. I easily picked up the nuances between the languages and can easily switch between JavaScript and Python now.
I'm excited to delve deeper into Python and explore its applications, especially in backend development with Django. The more I learn, the more confident I feel about my coding skills.

I have to watch how I code. I tend to stick with what I know. For example, I was completely content just using for loops to iterate over arrays and objects in JS but I had to force myself to use the built-in methods. Now I love them and hardly ever use traditional for loops. This week, I created a blackjack terminal game in Python. I made it in about 2 hours with a functional programming approach. Then I caught myself getting too comfortable and forced myself to only use classes to learn Object-Oriented Programming (OOP). It took me 2 days to get as far as I did staying in my comfort zone. I need to consciously decide to take the seemingly harder routes that I know will be good for me and the projects in the long run.

Overall, this week was great and I learned a lot about Python and OOP. Iâ€™m feeling really confident in my skills. I also did super well in a mock JS interview with Ember which boosted my confidence. I canâ€™t wait to keep learning more about Python and backend development!

week11.title: Diving into Databases
week11.introParagraph: This week was the hardest week of the bootcamp for me, with a fast introduction to both SQL and Django's ORM.
headings: Navigating Steep Learning Curves
Challenges with Django
Excitement for Database Structures
Project Momentum
paragraphs: Learning SQL on Monday was draining, and then immediately learning how to interact with a SQL database through Django's ORM was a very quick abstraction and difficult to grasp. But I love a challenge, and I'm proud of myself for doing all the reading and getting all the reps in to finally feel confident with the basics of Django and SQL.

Backend development will take some getting used to, but I have learned that planning out the structure of a relational database really gets me excited. I think it's super fun to think about how everything relates to each other. The biggest sticking point I had was I erroneously linked two tables with a one-to-many relationship, but I really wanted a many-to-many. This caused me to spend all of Thursday refactoring my code.
I'm still going strong. I felt a little burnt out on reading articles and doing w3school practices, but once we started the project on Wednesday, I got back in the groove!
All that said, I still can't wait to use React in our projects again. ðŸ˜‚
